metadata.titleEn: Distribution data of retrogressive thaw slump in permafrost zone of Qinghai-Tibet Plateau (2018-2020)
metadata.description: This dataset contain the retrogressive thaw slump (RTS) inventory in permafrost region of the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau (QTP) based on field investigations and the manual interpretation of the Gaofen-1 and Gaofen-2 images. RTSs were visually detected based on the presence of recently exposed sediments, poorly developed vegetation, and distinct headwalls. To avoid misdelineation of the RTS, the entire permafrost region of the QTP was divided into a large number of grids measuring 5 × 5 km each. Grids with slope degrees below 1° or higher than 15° were excluded because RTSs are rarely found at these slopes according to our previous study and field investigations. RTSs in the remaining grids were detected and sketched by the first author and then examined by at least two other experienced authors. Once a RTS was identified, it was assigned a unique number and classified based on its initiation such as next to a river (R), by lake erosion (L), and after the occurrence of  active-layer detachment slide (A).
metadata.instructions: The retrogressive thaw slump distribution data to the RTS - QTP. SHP format, file storage the latitude, longitude, perimeter and area of the retrogressive thaw slump , can be directly loaded into the ArcGIS software for editing.

background: The Qinghai–Tibet Plateau (QTP) is referred to as the world's “third pole” and is characterized by a warming rate that has been more than twice the global average during the past five decades. Significant changes in air temperature have resulted in wide permafrost degradation thereon. Retrogressive thaw slump refers to the failure of a hill slope associated with exposed ground ice thawing and the subsequent slumping of thawed soil. It is a common landform associated with permafrost thawing or degradation in permafrost regions. Widespread RTS activity has been observed in most Arctic and subarctic permafrost regions in recent years in association with persistent climate warming and permafrost degradation. Early studies on RTSs in the permafrost region of the QTP mainly focused on the Qinghai–Tibet Engineering Corridor and generally treated the RTS as an adverse engineering geological phenomenon. Due to its unique and high-altitude environment, the QTP accounts for more than half of the alpine permafrost in the world, with a specific permafrost area of ∼1.06 × 10^6 km^2. Permafrost on the QTP is relatively ice-rich and field monitoring results confirmed that the ground ice content is mainly controlled by the moisture availability, slope direction, and fine-particle content. The permafrost in the QTP is generally within a few degrees below the freezing point and has experienced noticeable warming over the past decades. The active layer thickness (ALT) of permafrost on the QTP generally ranges from 1 to 4 m, with an average value of ∼2.2 m.
research objective: Due to the increasing air temperatures, retrogressive thaw slumps (RTSs) have become more common on the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau (QTP), but their inventory, frequency, and initiation have not been fully investigated. Therefore, we compiled an inventory of active RTSs within the permafrost area on the QTP with a size of 1.06 × 10^6 km^2 based on high-resolution satellite image interpretation and field Global Position System positioning. We also explored the correlations between the spatial distribution of RTSs and terrain factors, surface deposits, and the permafrost ice content. To further investigate the frequency of RTS occurrence, the annual dynamics of RTSs in three typical areas between 2008/2013 and 2021 were documented using a time series of satellite imagery. This is the first study in which a large-scale RTS data set is provided and the first one in which the distribution and frequency of RTSs on the entire QTP are reported.
challenges: RTSs were not considered to be widespread throughout the QTP. However, RTS activity has been observed more frequently in recent years. Although the distribution and growth of RTSs have been reported in certain small regions, they have not been quantified or effectively analyzed within the entire permafrost region of the QTP. Because of these diverse radiometric characteristics within one RTS and spectra similar to those of other land cover types, it is difficult to automatically map RTSs in images using traditional computer classification methods. Training samples and the algorithm's code must be significantly adjusted when used for different images and locations, which makes it difficult to utilize this deep learning algorithm for the large-scale mapping of RTSs throughout the entire QTP.
methods: Orthographic Gaofen-1 and Gaofen-2 images captured between 2018 and 2020 were used to delineate the RTS boundaries in the entire permafrost region of the QTP. In addition, time series of orthographic satellite images (resolution ≥2.5 m) from 2008 or 2013 to 2021 were acquired to estimate the annual changes of RTSs in three typical regions. We visually interpreted RTSs in this study. During the three surveys, 189 RTSs were recorded in the field. For the implementation of the Second Tibetan Plateau Scientific Expedition and Research program, the overall distribution of RTSs in the central QTP was systematically investigated between January and June 2021.
dataset: Orthographic Gaofen-1 and Gaofen-2 images captured between 2018 and 2020 were used to delineate the RTS boundaries in the entire permafrost region of the QTP. In addition, time series of orthographic satellite images (resolution ≥2.5 m) from 2008 or 2013 to 2021 were acquired to estimate the annual changes of RTSs in three typical regions. Air temperature at a height of 2 m and precipitation data from two national meteorological stations (Wudaoliang and Tuotuohe) from 2013 to 2021 were used to characterize the climatic conditions.
findings: In satellite imagery for the period 2018–2020, 2669 active RTSs were identified in permafrost regions of the QTP. Most of the RTSs occur in regions with elevations ranging from 4,600 to 5,100 m along north-facing slopes varying from 3° to 8°. The number of RTSs and their affected areas increased by 4 and 6 times, respectively, in three densely distributed RTS regions from 2008/2013 to 2021. We observed that the number and areas of RTSs significantly increased during the last 12 years. We also determined that such increases mainly occurred in 2010 and 2016 when the air temperature was extremely high. Anomalously high air temperatures during the thawing season might be the main reason for the recent RTS acceleration on the QTP.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to map retrogressive thaw slumps (RTSs) in permafrost regions?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method used to map RTSs in permafrost regions is the visual interpretation of orthographic Gaofen-1 and Gaofen-2 satellite images captured between 2018 and 2020. This method involves delineating RTS boundaries across the permafrost areas of the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when trying to automatically map RTSs using remote sensing data?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge in automatically mapping RTSs is the difficulty in distinguishing them from other land cover types due to diverse radiometric characteristics within one RTS and spectra similar to those of other land covers. This requires significant adjustments to training samples and algorithm codes for different images and locations.

Example.Question: Can you give an example of a dataset that characterizes climatic conditions affecting RTSs in permafrost regions?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset that characterizes climatic conditions affecting RTSs includes air temperature at a height of 2 meters and precipitation data from two national meteorological stations (Wudaoliang and Tuotuohe) collected from 2013 to 2021.

Definition.Question: What does 'retrogressive thaw slump (RTS)' mean in the context of permafrost studies?
Definition.Answer: Retrogressive thaw slump refers to the failure of a hill slope associated with exposed ground ice thawing and the subsequent slumping of thawed soil. It is a common landform associated with permafrost thawing or degradation in permafrost regions.

Definition.Question: What does 'active layer thickness (ALT)' signify in the context of permafrost research on the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau?
Definition.Answer: The active layer thickness (ALT) refers to the depth of the permafrost that thaws during the warm season and refreezes during the cold season. On the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau, it generally ranges from 1 to 4 meters, with an average value of approximately 2.2 meters.

Comparison.Question: What differences exist between the data collection challenges faced when using high-resolution satellite imagery versus traditional computer classification methods in mapping RTSs across the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau?
Comparison.Answer: When using high-resolution satellite imagery, the challenge lies in the manual interpretation required to accurately delineate RTSs due to diverse radiometric characteristics and spectral similarities to other land cover types. Traditional computer classification methods struggle with automatically mapping RTSs in images due to these same challenges, and they require significant adjustments in training samples and algorithmic code for different images and locations, limiting their scalability across the entire plateau.

Comparison.Question: How does the incorporation of air temperature and precipitation data from national meteorological stations enhance the understanding of RTS occurrence compared to relying solely on satellite imagery?
Comparison.Answer: Incorporating air temperature and precipitation data from national meteorological stations provides critical climatic context that enhances the understanding of RTS occurrence by correlating environmental conditions with RTS activity. While satellite imagery captures spatial distribution and changes over time, meteorological data reveals the influence of climatic factors, such as anomalously high air temperatures during thawing seasons, which are pivotal in explaining recent increases in RTS activity.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the difficulty of automatically mapping retrogressive thaw slumps (RTSs) using traditional computer classification methods?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The difficulty in automatically mapping RTSs arises from the diverse radiometric characteristics within one RTS and the spectra that are similar to those of other land cover types. Training samples and algorithm codes need significant adjustments for different images and locations, complicating the large-scale mapping of RTSs.

Causal Consequence.Question: What outcomes are expected when using high-resolution satellite images for delineating RTS boundaries in permafrost regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using high-resolution satellite images, such as orthographic Gaofen-1 and Gaofen-2 images, allows for the detailed delineation of RTS boundaries in permafrost regions, leading to the identification of 2669 active RTSs in permafrost regions of the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau. This approach helps in understanding the spatial distribution and growth patterns of RTSs.

Causal Consequence.Question: What could be the consequences of anomalously high air temperatures during the thawing season on RTS activity?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Anomalously high air temperatures during the thawing season might lead to significant increases in the number and areas of RTSs, as observed with a substantial rise in RTS activity during years of extremely high temperatures, such as 2010 and 2016. This acceleration in RTS activity is primarily attributed to the warming climatic conditions.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to use high-resolution satellite image interpretation and field GPS positioning for data collection in permafrost regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Using high-resolution satellite image interpretation and field GPS positioning is important for accurately delineating RTS boundaries and compiling an inventory of active RTSs within the permafrost area on the QTP. This approach allows for detailed documentation of the spatial distribution and annual dynamics of RTSs.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals behind investigating the correlations between RTSs' spatial distribution and factors like terrain, surface deposits, and permafrost ice content?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goals behind investigating these correlations are to better understand the factors influencing RTS distribution and growth, and to identify patterns that may be associated with permafrost degradation. This understanding can help in predicting future RTS activity and in assessing the impact of climate change on permafrost regions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are used to accurately delineate RTS boundaries in permafrost regions using satellite imagery?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Orthographic Gaofen-1 and Gaofen-2 images captured between 2018 and 2020 are used to delineate RTS boundaries in the entire permafrost region of the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau through visual interpretation.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are changes in retrogressive thaw slump occurrences monitored over time in the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Time series of orthographic satellite images with a resolution of 2.5 m or better, spanning from 2008/2013 to 2021, are used to estimate the annual changes in RTSs in three typical regions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What challenges are faced when mapping RTSs in the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau using traditional computer classification methods?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Mapping RTSs is challenging due to diverse radiometric characteristics within one RTS and the spectra's similarity to other land cover types, requiring significant adjustments to training samples and algorithms for different images and locations.

Enablement.Question: What data collection methods have enabled the accurate mapping of retrogressive thaw slumps in the permafrost regions of the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: The use of orthographic Gaofen-1 and Gaofen-2 satellite images captured between 2018 and 2020 enabled the delineation of retrogressive thaw slump boundaries. Additionally, time series of orthographic satellite images (resolution ≥2.5 m) from 2008 or 2013 to 2021 were acquired to estimate the annual changes of retrogressive thaw slumps in three typical regions.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of satellite imagery with field surveys facilitate the inventory and monitoring of retrogressive thaw slumps in permafrost areas?
Enablement.Answer: Field surveys recorded 189 retrogressive thaw slumps, which were then integrated with satellite imagery to provide a comprehensive inventory and monitoring of retrogressive thaw slumps. This approach allowed for the systematic investigation of their overall distribution in central Qinghai-Tibet Plateau between January and June 2021.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or factors have influenced the increase in retrogressive thaw slump activity in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau's permafrost regions?
Enablement.Answer: The increase in retrogressive thaw slump activity is mainly influenced by anomalously high air temperatures during the thawing season, which have accelerated RTS occurrences. Notably, significant increases were observed in 2010 and 2016 when air temperatures were extremely high.

Expectation.Question: Why might it be challenging to automatically map retrogressive thaw slumps (RTSs) in images using traditional computer classification methods?
Expectation.Answer: Because of the diverse radiometric characteristics within one RTS and spectra similar to those of other land cover types, it is difficult to automatically map RTSs in images using traditional computer classification methods.

Expectation.Question: Why might the number of RTSs and their affected areas significantly increase during certain years?
Expectation.Answer: Anomalously high air temperatures during the thawing season might be the main reason for the recent RTS acceleration on the QTP, which was notably observed in the years 2010 and 2016.

Expectation.Question: Why is it necessary to use both high-resolution satellite image interpretation and field Global Position System positioning to compile an inventory of active RTSs within the permafrost area?
Expectation.Answer: Due to the difficulty in automatically mapping RTSs and the need for accurate identification, high-resolution satellite image interpretation combined with field GPS positioning is necessary to compile an inventory of active RTSs within the permafrost area on the QTP.

Judgmental.Question: How effective do you think the manual visual interpretation of satellite images is for accurately mapping RTS boundaries in permafrost regions, considering potential challenges in image classification?
Judgmental.Answer: Manual visual interpretation of satellite images, as used in the permafrost regions of the QTP, is challenging due to diverse radiometric characteristics and spectral similarities with other land cover types, making automatic mapping difficult with traditional methods. However, it allows for detailed observation and can be effective if combined with expert reviews, as demonstrated by the systematic investigation and review process described.

Judgmental.Question: What are your views on the potential limitations and advantages of using orthographic Gaofen-1 and Gaofen-2 images for delineating RTS boundaries over large areas like the QTP?
Judgmental.Answer: Orthographic Gaofen-1 and Gaofen-2 images provide high-resolution data, which is advantageous for delineating RTS boundaries across large areas like the QTP. However, the need for manual interpretation and the challenges in capturing diverse radiometric characteristics may limit their effectiveness in large-scale, automated mapping without substantial manual input and expertise.

Training samples and the algorithm's code must be significantly adjusted when used for different images and locations.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how climatic conditions are integrated into the analysis of RTS distribution and changes.
Assertion.Answer: Air temperature at a height of 2 m and precipitation data from two national meteorological stations (Wudaoliang and Tuotuohe) from 2013 to 2021 were used to characterize the climatic conditions in the analysis of RTS distribution and changes.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the data collection methods used to identify and delineate retrogressive thaw slump boundaries on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau.
Request/Directive.Answer: Orthographic Gaofen-1 and Gaofen-2 satellite images captured between 2018 and 2020 were visually interpreted to delineate retrogressive thaw slump (RTS) boundaries in the permafrost region of the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau. Time series of satellite images with a resolution of 2.5 m or higher, spanning from 2008 or 2013 to 2021, were also acquired to assess the annual changes in RTSs in three typical regions. This approach involved both remote sensing imagery and field GPS positioning.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe the challenges faced in the automated mapping of retrogressive thaw slumps using traditional computer classification methods.
Request/Directive.Answer: The automated mapping of retrogressive thaw slumps (RTSs) is challenged by the diverse radiometric characteristics within one RTS and the spectral similarities to other land cover types. Traditional computer classification methods struggle with these variations, requiring significant adjustments to training samples and algorithm codes for different images and locations. This complexity makes it difficult to effectively utilize deep learning algorithms for large-scale RTS mapping across the entire Qinghai-Tibet Plateau.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential datasets that could be used to characterize climatic conditions affecting retrogressive thaw slumps on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets to characterize climatic conditions affecting retrogressive thaw slumps on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau include air temperature data at a height of 2 meters and precipitation data from national meteorological stations such as Wudaoliang and Tuotuohe. These datasets, spanning from 2013 to 2021, provide insights into the climatic factors influencing RTS activity.
